Hi Matt,

I think to a certain extent it's dependent on your population siz=
e. 
Larger populations are more tolerant of more species.

I think most of =
the current NEAT implementations clamp the number of
species...something li=
ke 5-8 (please correct me if I'm wrong on this).
 Obviously if you only hav=
e 1 species, you're not exploiting its
advantages...likewise if you have a =
population of 100 and you have 100
species (everyone is in their own specie=
s), you're not getting any
crossover.

ANJI doesn't clamp the number of spe=
cies, and so we end up tuning the
threshold manually.  We usually end up wi=
th somewhere between 20-30
species in a typical run.

Theoretically, I like=
 to think of species as camps moving out into the
search space and explorin=
g.  They're clusters of similar solutions in
the fitness landscape.  You do=
n't want too many and you don't want too
few.  And you want a certain amoun=
t of turnover or dynamism, because
you want to encourage more exploration, =
and probably have some search
spaces abandoned in favor of more promising o=
nes.

Others may have some insights into why they clamped the species size.=


The short answer, though not very helpful, is somewhere between 1 and
you=
r population size. :)

Derek

On 9/7/05, Matt Simmerson <m.simmerson@btopen=
world.com> wrote:
> Hi
> 
> Just wondering if anyone has any view as to the=
 optimum(ish) number of
> species.  My implementation will cope with both a=
 fixed and dynamic
> compatability threshold so I can control the number of=
 species to a
> certain degree.
> 
> I find that with a fixed CT, the numbe=
r of species decline eventually
> to just a few, after intially having many=
 (tens/hundreds).
> 
> Thoughts, opinoins etc very much welcomed.
> 
> Chee=
rs
